those are always fun.  I think I had more trouble with :root { line-height: 1rem } than :root { font-size: 1rem; }

yes, except you need to remember to special-case the root
in our codebase, at least
ah
this particular infinite loop was that <input> in <select> implies </select> and then reprocesses the token
but if you're setting the innerHTML on a <select>, the </select> is ignored
so nothing changed, and reprocessing the token just tries again
since otherwise you get:  go off and find the root element and get its style... oh wait, it doesn't have one, let's compute it ... ad inf.
nice

- is it tied to a requirement to implement vanilla OTF/TTF (or is the latter otherwise placed on an equal footing)?

othermaciej (or anyone who might know), how much of videoElement.canPlayType() does safari support?
mpilgrim: we support it, I think it may be buggy in some cases (depending on what release)
including the codecs parameter?
yes, we look at the codecs parameter
I think the last released Safari may have a bug with properly detecting that XiphQT is installed. It should be fixed in 4.0.3, once that is out.
use case: http://wearehugh.com/public/2006/12/video.html
via markup, it works fine (tested in latest release of safari 4.0.x, on windows)
i want to write a script that asks the browser whether it can play that video
"mp4creator -list 20061225.mp4" says it contains an MPEG-4 AAC LC audio track
I believe asking about video/mp4 with the proper codecs parameter will work from script
and an H264 Baseline (level 1.3) video track
(in an MP4 container, obviously)
how would i format the codecs parameter to test that particular combination?
I am not an expert on the details of the mpeg-4 codecs parameter values, but I think the example of one in the spec would work
though it may not encapsulate exactly that profile set
the example in the spec always returns "maybe"
is that the most confident answer i can expect?
or is there another input that would return "probably"?
I think we might be wrong about when exactly we say "maybe" vs "probably"
but we won't say "no" (or, in the next version, "") for a codec we can actually play
i have quicktime installed
but v.canPlayType("video/mp4;codecs=avc1.42E01E,mp4a.40.2") returns "maybe" in win/safari 4.0.2
but returns "probably" in chrome 3.0.196.2
(both browsers can play a video matching that codec parameter)
chrome lies, so that's not necessarily a good data point
although I think they may have fixed that bug
i think that's fixed now
hmm
v.canPlayType("video/mp4;codecs=foobar") returns "maybe" (chrome 3.0.196.2)
I think Safari and Chrome both have bugs here
some are in the cross-platform media element code perhaps, and some are likely in the media engine back ends

So, I'm building a thin feature-testing library for myself for html5.  Safari and Opera both support <input type=range>, but neither of them properly validate input.  Should I mark them as supporting or not?
I'm mainly going to use this to decide whether or not to feed the user a jQuery library to simulate the control.
Xanthir: define "properly validate"
Given an invalid @value, they'll return "" (should be halfway between min and max).  Given an out-of-bounds @value, they return the value unchanged.
The latter should be clamped to [min,max].
filed bugs?
Xanthir: If they are both wrong in the same way maybe the spec should be changed
hasn't looked at this in detail
virtuelv: Not yet - I was just working on this last night for myself.
neither have I, but the behavior Xanthir is suggesting seems more sensible
jgraham: possibly.  The behavior they exhibit with an invalid value is consistent with how other sanitizing types work (like the date and time types).
But I'm definitely not happy with how they handle an overflow/underflow value, nor a non-provided value.
Oh, and sorry if I was implying that the behavior I'm wanting is my own invention.  It's from the spec, virtuelv.
Xanthir: no, I'm not seeing that implication
Ah, k.  Good.  ^_^
I'm just saying that the spec seems to make sense in this case
the spec is missing error handling when setting HTMLInputElement.value, though
Nod.  It guarantees that the return value of an <input type=range> is a number within the range at all times.
Hm, possibly, but I was setting the value on initialization.  I was using jQuery with $("<input type=range value=foo>").val()
Which, by spec, should return 50 (default min/max is 0/100, so midway between them is 50).
Xanthir: I agree that not clamping seems odd.
The halfway between min and max seems totally arbitary
points out http://philip.html5.org/data/charsets.html in relation to the charset discussion
It's just a way of defining the 'default' value.  Safari will start a range input on the halfway mark.
But it still returns "" if you didn't set a @value, and haven't touched it yet.
Oh wait, that's lies.  It correctly returns 50 if you just put a range input onto the page and immediately ask it for the value.
But it still sanitizes an invalid value to "".

Ah, no, I got it.  Safari will return 50 for the value of a static <input type=range> in the page.  It returns "" for a freshly-created one that hasn't been inserted into the document yet.  Not sure of exact details on how this works.
I guess I'll go file some bugs today.

sessionStorage should work for iframes
but not separate top-level windows (or top-level browsing contexts, as they're called)

jgraham: yeah, i think if more people tried to do this there'd be a sudden realisation of the usefulness of @summary

Well, not necessarily.  Another possibility is the realization that we can generate useful automated summaries for simple tables, and that summaries are too difficult to generate even for humans for complex tables - blind people are just fucked in that case.
In other words, in the first case machines can do summaries, so there's no reason to let humans do it, and in the second case humans can't do summaries, so letting them try is a fool's game.
Well, some humans can do it
yeah, but how does a summary help a blind person or a person with learning difficulties if I can't even draw a table from a summary?
or do I miss a point somewhere?

beowulf: I'm saying that it may be true that @summary is never a useful attribute to expose.  ^_^
If I take the summaries that people provide for the tables they are given, and ask others who haven't seen the tables to reconstruct the structure of the table and see how well they do
Xanthir: i think I agree
When a summary would help a blind person, a machine can do it sufficiently well.  When a summary wouldn't, not even a human can summarize it properly.
There may be a middle ground of tables that are understandable through their summary, but are too complex to machine-generate a good one for.
That'd be fun, Lach.
Given any particular algorithm for deriving summaries, I can't imagine it would be too hard to find an example which it doesn't handle but which can be trivially explained by a human
Likely true.  But further questions must be answered:
1) Can humans reliably explain tables well?

I'm not convinved about the ability for a computer to automatically generate a summary from a table in a way that would provide any more information to a user than they would obtain by manually scanning the table headers
2) If no, or at least partially no, is that 'middle class' of tables common enough to justify allowing bad summaries to float around for tables that *can* be machine-summarized?
That's roughly what I'm talking about, Lachy.
do sighted people summarise tables?
There's a clear class of simple tables where that is good enough, and while allowing a human to write a summary might produce a better/shorter one, it might also produce a *worse* one.
So, some tests about people's ability to summarize tables well would be cool.
or do we just interogate them using axis as guides?
Also: tests concerning current @summary use and usefulness.
Xanthir, I'm planning to do such a study
Yeah, I know, I heard you a page ago.  ^_^  I'm just making it clear what my point was.
I'm in the process of developing the methodology, but soon I will need to find or create some actual tables that I can get authors to mark up

beowulf: that's a good question.  If the prevalent methodology of sighted people is to just use them for a row/col lookup based on the headers, then that might indicate that a simple listing of row/column headers is rather useful.
But if we do approach most tables more holistically, then perhaps that sort of machine-generated approach isn't so useful.

but then if that's the case it's not a summary of a table you need for access, it's a whole new macguffin entirely, no?
